(outlines, semi outlines, no outlines, soft paint strokes)

metadata.name: Gribouillis #152
metadata.description:
"Gribouillis" tends to reproduce the result of what you could draw without too much thinking on your sketchbook; an automatic drawing while listening to a call or podcast... Or something you would draw on the napkin of a restaurant without a strong focus...
Those kind of drawing that don't have a lot of meaning, but that, sometimes, give you find some comfort.

---

This is a "screenshot" of the current researches and work I'm doing to emulate a sensation of sketching.

---

Open the link and add '#hd' in the URL to have a A3 size of the artwork.

---

Made to run in browser, especially Chrome.
Works on most recent iPhones.

---

Twitter: @florianzumbrunn
Instagram: @florianzumbrunn

attributes.name: Color Style
attributes.value: Palette - Sketch from an old book

metadata.name: Pixel Management #2175
metadata.description:
#tezpole has demonstrated to us all the importance of effective Cable Management. Intrigued by this challenge, I've delved deep into the pixels of this issue. 🙂

Drawing inspiration from Rev Dan Catt’s 'Tally!' and applying similar principles of Cable Management, I've assembled a fun and free OE project.

This project dynamically evolves with each iteration.Grid is determined by a random value calculated as follows: the lower bound starts at 3 and increases incrementally with every 100 iterations, while the upper bound starts at 4 and increases with every 30 iterations. In practical terms, as the iteration count increases, both the minimum and maximum possible number of cols&rows gradually increase.

3200x3200px
Press [s] for .jpeg | Press [p] for .png
Made with p5.js

Rob Scalera | 2023

metadata.name: Emotional Shell #180
metadata.description:
Manual Dutch Auction (DA): 72 · 54 · 40 · 30 · 24 · 20 every 8 minutes.
Auction will stop changing price when non-reserves are fully minted, and then drop one price tier.

---------

The feeling of being human – with all of its intricate hopes, struggles, and fleeting emotions – seems so unique that we assume artificial intelligence could never replicate our experience. And while we devise systems for solving unfathomably complex problems, generating algorithmic creativity, and unlocking regenerative biological possibilities, we simultaneously cling to the power and originality of emotional feeling – believing it to be the irreplaceable source of what makes us human.

If the body is our shell for emotion and soul, can an artificial humanoid be another vessel for these thoughts and feelings – for human essence itself? If our ‘soul’ is the last stand between us and the machines, what happens when the soul becomes transferable? That we may see answers to these questions looks more real every year, and is perhaps a little frightening. 

Emotional Shell uses introspective portraits of future selves to question what it means to be human, when the people around us are no longer human.

---------

Warning: This piece is GPU intensive, it may not render on lower end devices.

Press 1-3 to select from low, medium, and high quality settings
Press 'S' to save the image at the current scale
Press 'H' to save the image at 2400px resolution

Created with Three.js
For third party license information, please see bundle.js.LICENSE.txt

---------

TENDER x wwatkns
August 2022

metadata.name: <iframes> #497
metadata.description:
The <iframe> HTML element is an element that allows a web document to embed the contents of another web document within itself. iframes are at the core of fxhash. They are portals opening our view to rich content.

This work is a portal to itself. It loads itself within itself 20 times. It's not pretty, it reminds us of WordArt, it's a little bit hacky, it might break when our tools to display HTML will change. But it's a proof that the limits of our tools are only limits until creativity breaks them.

This work is not purely deterministic, because it simply cannot be. Slight timing differences due to loading times being different each time an <iframe> is loaded will make each visualization slightly unique.

If you view this token on mobile, the nesting limit was reduced to 4 to prevent performance issues.

This work is highly experimental. It leverages a "hack" to allow iframes to be nested.
Firefox max <iframe> nesting depth as of 28/12/2021 is capped at 9.
Works with chrome desktop 96.0.4664.110

metadata.name: Ir/rational Beauty #149
metadata.description:
Released on the occasion of the Tribute to Herbert W. Franke. www.tribute-hwf.com

"Since the classical age of Greece, the golden ratio has been well known as the most balanced and therefore most aesthetically perfect proportion. In fact, it is supposedly often found in the fine arts and architecture and it is certainly important in geometry. But where is the proof that it is really the most beautiful proportion?

"The computer is proving to be a useful tool in exact art theory. Works of computer art are produced with the help of programs that describe the logic of the construction and its relevant measures. By varying the parameters you can vary the shapes of objects, and on the basis of the reaction of the public you can determine the best option. So it is possible to find valid rules to design works of art.

"A statistical evaluation would be interesting. Please email me with your results for the optimal proportion."

I found it heartwarming that in 2011, Herbert W. Franke wrote the above, accompanied with a simple functional program on a Wolfram Demonstration page (https://demonstrations.wolfram.com/IsTheGoldenRatioReallyTheMostBeautifulProportion/) titled 'Is the Golden Ratio Really the Most Beautiful Proportion?' and invited people to submit their findings to him.

The main idea behind this project is ratios, a variety of them, used in a variety of ways, such as how a rectangle is repeatedly subdivided, or how it influences the aspect ratio of the piece, or how the colors in a palette are selected. These are represented in various styles, some of which are inspired by the aesthetic of Herbert W. Franke's diverse artworks, and his openness to experimentation with new technologies, such as plotter drawings, screens, screenprints, or 2D and 3D digital renderings.

This project, while not designed to be a formal statistical evaluation, is but my fun, colorful, and humble response to your inquiry, dear Herbert.

---

25% of primary sales will be donated on-chain to the Foundation Herbert W. Franke, with the goal of raising 20,000 Euros so that ZKM Karlsruhe can digitize Herbert W. Franke’s 1,800 manuscripts and make them publicly available. Any money raised beyond this goal will be donated to the Rütgers Foundation which supports children and young adults in Africa so that they can get access to and work with technology.

---

Controls:
• Double-click/tap or 'R' reassembles the piece (This automatically happens every minute)

Note: Some mints require WEBGL and/or may take several seconds to fully render.

Made in p5js
Created Oct 2022
Artist: @Yazid

metadata.name: Ordered Chaos #41
metadata.description:
Ordered Chaos is a dynamic interplay of precision and distortion, where structure and movement converge to form a captivating visual symphony. The artwork unfolds as a mosaic of geometric grids, vibrant hues, and flowing deformations, creating a sense of controlled entropy.

Bold colors—emerald greens, electric blues, fiery reds, and glowing yellows—dominate the composition, their contrasts breathing life into each segment. Rigid, orderly grids anchor the piece, yet these are disrupted by undulating lines and warped forms, suggesting an unseen force bending structure into fluidity.

The composition balances tension and harmony. Some sections radiate stability, showcasing clean, linear patterns, while others twist and contort, evoking motion and transformation. These distortions ripple across the surface, connecting the fragmented forms into a single cohesive flow—where chaos is not destruction but evolution.

Ordered Chaos reflects the duality of modern existence: a world shaped by digital precision and organic spontaneity. It invites viewers to immerse themselves in its patterns, to see order and disorder as two sides of the same whole, and to embrace the beauty that emerges when the two coexist in perfect tension.

metadata.name: Desend #21
metadata.description: Artworks presents blockchain transactions in an artistic form. The canvas depicts wallets and the number of tokens. Transactions, of course, go into blocks, and you can find an artistic way to represent blocks on this canvas. As an artistic representation of decentralization - the lines are not always straight, which reminds us of the branches of the blockchain, synchronization and consensus mechanisms.

metadata.name: Caught in a Void #499
metadata.description:
A reflection on the 571 days between the start of the COVID lockdown and quitting my job to be a generative artist.

Features include silhouette type, color palette, and fill effect.

p5.js

metadata.name: Tuesday #93
metadata.description: Maybe it's inspired by the marks left by coffee cups in my notebook. Maybe the doodles in that same notebook, often squares and circles, somehow influenced this work. Maybe the Bridget Riley book sitting on the shelf above gently whispered to me when I wasn't looking. Or maybe I just played with an idea and found it pleasing. The only thing I'm certain of – it was definitely a Tuesday.

metadata.name: Multi-Biome #110
metadata.description:
Inspired by Jose Margulis's "Alpine Landscape"

Designed to be viewed as if you're walking past on the gallery wall, Multi-Biome is an interative play on perspective and scale. Each landscape is created from between 50 and 200 planes, slicing the landscape along a single axis.

Click and drag to rotate.

Press "s" in live view to save a png.

metadata.name: Terrain Series, Quilt #24
metadata.description:
The first release from my experiments with terrain generation. 

Method: A quadtree is created from N number of randomly generated points. For each rectangle in the tree, particle points are created based on poisson disc sampling. The movement of these particles along the terrain + noise field is drawn with my rake-stroke method. The color of the rake-stroke is based on the noise value at the origin along with some other variability.

The loading time of the piece will be longer for some variations.
